{{ Infobox tennis circuit season | name = 2018 BWF Season | image = | image_caption = | image_alt = | image_size = | duration = 9 January – 22 December | edition = | tournaments = 136 | categories = Grade 1: 2 ([[2018 BWF World Championships|Individuals]], [[2018 Thomas & Uber Cup|Teams]])
Grade 2 - [[BWF World Tour Finals]]: 1
Grade 2 - [[BWF World Tour Super 1000|Super 1000]]: 3
Grade 2 - [[BWF World Tour Super 750|Super 750]]: 5
Grade 2 - [[BWF World Tour Super 500|Super 500]]: 7
Grade 2 - [[BWF World Tour Super 300|Super 300]]: 11
Grade 2 - [[BWF Tour Super 100|Super 100]]: 11
Grade 3 - [[BWF International Challenge|International Challenge]]: 22
Grade 3 - [[BWF International Series|International Series]]: 37
Grade 3 - [[BWF Future Series|Future Series]]: 27
Continental Championships: 10 | most_tournament_titles = | most_tournament_finals = | prize_money_leader = | points_leader = | player_of_the_year = {{flagicon|}} TBD | most promising player of the year = {{flagicon|}} TBD | previous = [[2017 BWF season|2017]] | next = [[2019 BWF season|2019]] }} The '''2018 BWF Season''' is the overall [[badminton]] circuit organized by the [[Badminton World Federation]] (BWF) for the 2018 badminton season to publish and promote the sport. Besides the [[BWF World Championships]], BWF promotes the sport of Badminton through an extensive worldwide program of events. These events have various purposes according to their level and territory in which they are held but those events owned by BWF seek to showcase the Sport via the widest possible quality television broadcast and build the fanbase of the Sport throughout the World. The world badminton tournament in 2018 consisted of: 1. BWF Tournaments (Grade 1 - Major Events) *BWF Men and Women's World Team Championships ([[2018 Thomas & Uber Cup]]: Thomas & Uber Cup) *BWF World Championships 2. BWF World Tour (Grade 2) The world badminton tournament structure has six levels: *Level 1 ([[BWF World Tour Finals]]) *Level 2 ([[BWF World Tour Super 1000]]) *Level 3 ([[BWF World Tour Super 750]]) *Level 4 ([[BWF World Tour Super 500]]) *Level 5 ([[BWF World Tour Super 300]]) *Level 6 (BWF Tour Super 100) 3. Continental Circuit (Grade 3) BWF Open Tournaments: [[BWF International Challenge]], [[BWF International Series]], and [[BWF Future Series]]. The Thomas Cup & Uber Cup, Sudirman Cup and Suhandinata Cup are Teams Events. The others – Super 1000, Super 750, Super 500, Super 300, Super 100, International Challenge, International Series, and Future Series are all individual tournaments. The higher the level of tournament, the larger the prize money and the more ranking points available.[http://bwfbadminton.com/2017/03/19/bwf-launches-new-event-structure/ "BWF Events"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419014400/http://bwfbadminton.com/2017/03/19/bwf-launches-new-event-structure/ |date=2017-04-19 }} ''[[Badminton World Federation]]'' The 2018 BWF Season calendar comprises these six levels of BWF tournaments. ==Schedule== This is the complete schedule of events on the 2018 calendar,[http://bwfcorporate.com/events/calendar/2018/all/0/-1/ "BWF Tournament Calendar – 2018"] ''[[Badminton World Federation]]'' with the Champions and Runners-up documented. ;Key {|class=wikitable style=font-size:80%;width:20% |-bgcolor=#F3E6D7 |World Championships |-bgcolor=#B6CDE5 |World Tour Finals |-bgcolor=#DAE4EA |Super 1000 |-bgcolor=#DEDEDC |Super 750 |-bgcolor=#E9E9E9 |Super 500 |-bgcolor=#C7F2D5 |Super 300 |-bgcolor=#D4F1C5 |Super 100 |-bgcolor=#F0CAF0 |International Challenge |-bgcolor=#FFDDF1 |International Series |-bgcolor=#FFFFA8 |Future Series |-bgcolor=#ECF2FF |Team events |} ===January=== {|class=wikitable style=font-size:80% |- !width=110|Week of !width=330|Tournament !width=250|Champions !width=250|Runners-up |- valign=top |rowspan=20|January 8 | style="background:#C7F2D5;" rowspan="10"| '''[[Thailand Masters (badminton)|Thailand Masters]]''' ([[2018 Thailand Masters (badminton)|Draw]]) *'''Host:''' [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] *'''Venue:''' [[Nimibutr Stadium]] *'''Level:''' [[BWF World Tour|Super 300]] *'''Prize:''' $150,000 *'''Format:''' 32MS/32WS/32MD/32WD/32XD |'''{{flagicon|INA}} [[Tommy Sugiarto]]''' |{{flagicon|MAS}} [[Leong Jun Hao]] |- |colspan=2| '''Score:''' 21–16, 21–15 |- valign=top |'''{{flagicon|THA}} [[Nitchaon Jindapol]]''' |{{flagicon|THA}} [[Pornpawee Chochuwong]] |- |colspan=2| '''Score:''' 21–11, 21–18 |- valign=top |'''{{flagicon|THA}} [[Tinn Isriyanet]]

revision.text:
[[File:24-Hour Run for Charity at Kandahar Airfield DVIDS395118.jpg|thumb|Service members and civilians stationed at Kandahar Airfield, Afghanistan, start the 24-Hour Run for Charity, April 16, 2011.]] A '''24-hour run''' is a form of [[ultramarathon]], in which a competitor runs as far as they can in 24 hours. They are typically held on 1- to 2-mile loops or occasionally 400-meter tracks.
Top runners will often run {{Convert|200|km|sigfig=3}} or more, depending on conditions, and the best can go beyond {{Convert|270|km|sigfig=3}}. Some participants will have a crew to help them, but others just set up a camp with all the gear and supplies they need near the starting area to access each loop. Often 24-hour events are combined with 6-, 12-, and 48-hour events. 24-hour runs have also been held in relay formats, with runners completing a mile each in succession for 24 hours. Often these events are not internationally sanctioned, and are more for charitable purposes.<ref>Bangor Daily News, Bangor, Maine, USA, Style Section, Page 17, "Marathon to raise money for American Cancer Society"</ref>
The [[List of world records in athletics|world records]] for the event on all surfaces are 258.339 km (160.524 miles) for women, set by [[Patrycja Bereznowska]] of Poland in 2017,<ref>{{cite news|title=Bereznowska sets world best at IAU 24 hour World Championships|url=https://www.iaaf.org/news/report/iau-24-hour-world-championships-2017-belfast|publisher=IAAF|author=Nadeem Khan|date=3 July 2017|accessdate=10 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180205130312/https://www.iaaf.org/news/report/iau-24-hour-world-championships-2017-belfast|archive-date=2018-02-05|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> and 303.506 km (188.590 miles) for men, set by [[Yiannis Kouros]] in 1997.
== Competitions == The first international championship was held February 3–4, 1990 in [[Milton Keynes]], [[England]].<ref>'Running' April 1990,Volume 108, p.6</ref> A full continental championship was formed in 1992 as the [[IAU 24 Hour European Championship]].<ref>[http://www.iau-ultramarathon.org/images/file/All%20Time%20Winners.xls All-Time Winners] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402100155/http://www.iau-ultramarathon.org/images/file/All%20Time%20Winners.xls |date=2015-04-02 }}. International Association of Ultrarunners. Retrieved on 2015-03-21.</ref>
The [[IAU 24 Hour World Championship]] is the pinnacle of competition in the 24-hour run. The first IAU Individual Track Championships were held in San Giovanni Lupatoto, Verona, Italy on 22–23 September 2001.<ref>Michiels, Paul & Milroy, Andy (2013-05-07). [https://www.arrs.run/HP_IAU24Hr.htm IAU 24 Hour Championships] . [[Association of Road Running Statisticians]]. Retrieved on 2015-03-21.</ref>
The German website DUV lists 160 24-hour races that were scheduled for 2012, a figure that has doubled over the last 10 years. The longest running 24-hour race is the [[Self-Transcendence 24 Hour Race Ottawa]], Canada which began in 1981.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.arrs.run/HP_Ott24H.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-10-01 |df= }}</ref>
A 24-hour race exclusively for youth was started in Hong Kong in 2010, and has continued annually (Running to Stop the Traffik).
== See also == * [[One hour run]] * [[12-hour run]] * [[Centurion (racewalking)|Centurion Walk]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://multidays.com/category/24-hour-races/ 24-Hour Race news and events] – Comprehensive worldwide 24 hour race calendar * [http://www.ultramarathonrunning.com/ ULTRAmarathonRunning.com] Global Ultramarathon Races & Events Calendar * [http://www.runultra.co.uk/ RunUltra.co.uk] Global Ultramarathon Races and Events Calendar with runner reviews * [http://www.harwichrunners.co.uk/hr24/ HR24] European 24 hour event

{{multiple issues| {{notability|Sport|date=October 2012}} {{unreferenced|date=October 2012}} }} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Astropark Ballingary | nickname = Astropark, Canons Field (old name) | image = | location = Knightstreet, [[Ballingarry, County Limerick|Ballingarry]] | coordinates = {{coord|52|28|11|N|8|52|11|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=it}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1984 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Ballingarry A.F.C.]] | operator = Seamus Burke | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 1,000 | dimensions = 54 x 24 yards |}}
'''Astropark Ballingarry''' is the home of [[Ballingarry A.F.C.]] who play in the [[Limerick Desmond League]]. The total capacity is 1,000.
==History==
Astropark Ballingarry is situated in [[Ballingarry, County Limerick|Ballingarry]], the heart of West Limerick, and is managed by Ballingarry AFC. A sponsored walk was organised, money was generated, and a pitch was secured in large part thanks to the generosity of the late Archdeacon Lyons. The club moved home to a pitch supplied by the late Bernard Sheehy at the rear of the 'Grove'.
==See also== * [[Ballingarry A.F.C.]]
[[Category:Association football venues in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Sports venues in County Limerick]]

{{redirect|Blow tube|the tools used in glass working|Glassblowing}} [[Image:Yahua Blowgun Amazon Iquitos Peru.jpg|thumb|300px|Demonstration of a blowgun by a [[Yahua]] hunter]]
A '''blowgun''' (also called a '''blowpipe''' or '''blow tube''') is a simple [[ranged weapon]] consisting of a long narrow tube for [[shooting]] light [[projectile]]s such as [[dart (missile)|dart]]s. It operates by having the projectile placed inside the pipe and using the force created by one's forced [[exhalation]] ("blow") to [[pneumatic]]ally propel the projectile. The propulsive power is limited by the user's strength of [[respiratory muscles]] and the [[vital capacity]] of the [[lung]]s.
==History== [[File:Cerbatana Tlacalhuazcuahuitl Bodley p38.jpg|thumb|[[Mixtec]] blowgun [[Tlacalhuazcuahuitl]] depicted in [[Codex Bodley]]]] Many cultures have used this weapon, but various indigenous peoples of [[Southeast Asia]], the [[Amazon Basin|Amazon]] and [[French Guiana|Guiana]] regions of [[South America]], and [[Guatemala]] in [[Central America]] are best known for its use.
Projectiles include seeds, clay pellets, and darts. Some cultures dip the tip of the darts in [[curare]] or other [[arrow poison]]s in order to paralyze the target. Blowguns were very rarely used by these tribes as [[anti-personnel weapon]]s, but primarily to hunt small game such as [[monkey]]s. [[Cherokee|North American Cherokees]] were known for making blowguns from [[Arundinaria|river cane]] to supplement their diet with [[rabbit]]s and other small creatures.
Blowguns are depicted in paintings on [[pre-Columbian]] pottery and are mentioned in many [[Mesoamerica]]n myths. Back then and today, the [[Maya peoples|Maya]] use a blowgun to hunt birds and small animals with spherical dry seeds and clay pellets. The clay ammunition is made slightly larger than needed (to allow for shrinkage and refinement) and stored in a shoulderbag. The outside of the dry clay pellet is shaved off and burnished right before use.<ref>Carol Ventura. "The Jakaltek Maya Blowgun in Mythological and Historical Context", in Ancient Mesoamerica 14.2: 257–268, 2003.</ref>
Shorter blowguns and smaller bore darts were used for [[varmint hunting]] by pre-adolescent boys in traditional Cherokee villages.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/962900055 Cherokee, Blowgun, Bibliography]. 2011. Contains a brief bibliography and article on the subject of blowguns.</ref> They used the blowguns to cut down on small rodents such as rats, mice, chipmunks and other mammals that cut or gnaw into food caches, seed and vegetable stores, or that are attracted to the planted vegetables. While this custom gave the boys something to do around the village and kept them out of mischief<ref>Health, Physical Education, Recreation a, and Hilliard, K. [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/930280498 An instructor's guide to traditional Native American games of the Eastern Band of the Cherokee: grades 5-8]. Middle Tennessee State University, 2014. Abstract: The purpose for this study was to develop a guide for instructors to use in understanding and teaching traditional games of the Eastern Band of the Cherokee. This guide is intended not only to provide an educational resource for instructors to use in teaching how to play traditional Eastern Band of the Cherokee games, but also as a resource to utilize in passing on historical and traditional information about each game. In creating this study the researcher identified two major topics to be reviewed: (1) Historical information relating to Native American culture with an emphasis on the Eastern Band of the Cherokee and traditional games of the Eastern Band (to provide a historical background of each game, including traditional purposes, how each game was played, traditional equipment, and other beneficial information for instructors and students). (2) Curriculum development information (to guide the researcher in developing the components and format for the instructor's guide). After reviewing the historical information available through interviews and literature, three categories of Eastern Band of the Cherokee games were found. These categories include games of skill and dexterity; games of amusement; and games of chance. Within the games of skill and dexterity category ten traditional Eastern Band of the Cherokee games were noted: arrow/dart throwing, tipping, and tossing games; blowgun games; chunkey; cornstalk shooting; a hunting game; kickball; marbles; a running game; stickball; and tug-of-war. Within the games of amusement category only one traditional Eastern Band of the Cherokee game was noted, a string game called Crow's Feet. Within the games of chance category there was also only one traditional Eastern Band of the Cherokee game found, a basket dice tossing game called Jacksnap. After reviewing the curriculum development literature, the Tennessee Instructional Model (1984) was selected for the overall design of the instructor's guide, with the added features of photographs of traditional equipment, when available, and lead-up activities which teach the skills necessary to play each game. By combining the Native American historical information and curriculum development information the instructor's guide was created, which includes an introduction to the Eastern Band of the Cherokee people and detailed lesson plans for each traditional game. The guidebook was constructed for the developmental characteristics of students in the fifth through the eighth grade. It is hoped that this guidebook will serve as a tool for instructors to use in keeping alive the history and traditions of the Eastern Band of the Cherokee games.</ref>, it also worked as an early form of pest control.<ref>Ruehl, Ron, and Lawson S. Warren. [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49193041 Hayes Lossiah: Cherokee Blowgun Maker]. Raleigh, N.C.: N.C. Dept. of Cultural Resources, 1985. Summary: This program, set during the Cherokee fall festival in North Carolina, highlights the work of Hayes Lossiah, Cherokee craftsman and blowgun maker. Lossiah demonstrates the construction of a traditional Cherokee blowgun.</ref> Some food was also obtained by the boys, who hunted squirrels with blowguns well into the 20th century.<ref>Smith, Jim "Crow". 2017. "The Modern Blowgun". [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/12739327 The Backwoodsman] "The magazine for the twentieth century frontiersman specializing in trapping, woodslore, survival, gardening, muzzleloading & homesteading". Volume 38. September/October 2017. Pages 58–60.</ref>
Today blowguns are used with tranquilizer darts to capture wildlife or to stun caged dangerous animals. [[Herpetology|Herpetologists]] use blowguns to capture elusive [[lizard]]s with stun darts. Blowguns are also used recreationally, with either darts or paintballs.
==Sport blowgun== There are several competition styles practised around the world. A standardization of competition style, based upon [[fukiya]], is being pursued by the International Fukiyado Association and hopes to become an Olympic event. It is a {{convert|10|m|ft|adj=on}} target shooting, using a standardized barrel caliber and length, and a standardized dart length and weight as outlined by IFA.
Two other styles are also being pursued to make up the Olympic blowgun event, both based upon the Cherokee Annual Gathering Blowgun Competition. The Field Style competition is similar to the winter Biathlon, where the shooter runs from a starting line to a target lane, shoots and retrieves the darts, and continues to the next station. The course length varies from {{cvt|400|to|800|m|yd|-1}} or longer, with from 9 to 16 targets at various heights and shooting distances. The final style is the Long Distance target shoot. The target is a circle of {{cvt|24|cm|in|0}} diameter, and the firing line is {{cvt|20|m|ft|0}} away. Three darts are fired by each shooter, at least one of which must stick in the target. All successful shooters move to the next round, moving back {{cvt|2|m|ft|1}} each time.
Sport blowgun competition is managed by the International Fukiyado Association with which national associations in the United States, France, Germany and the Philippines are affiliated.
== Gallery == <gallery class="center" mode="packed" heights="200px"> Image:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Dajak met blaasroer TMnr 10013424.jpg|A [[Dayak people|Dayak]] man using a blowgun, [[Indonesia]], circa 1920 File:Rivercane blowgun quiver shawna cain.jpg|[[Rivercane]] quiver with blowgun darts, fletched with [[bull thistle]] Image:Blowgun demonstration in Oconaluftee Indian Village, Cherokee, North Carolina.jpg|Demonstration of [[Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians|Eastern Cherokee]] blowgun in [[Oconaluftee Indian Village]], [[Cherokee, North Carolina]] File:Achuar con cerbatana (Amazonía Ecuatoriana).jpg|An [[Achuar people|Achuar]] man with a blowgun, [[Ecuador]] File:JacaltekMayaBlowgun.jpg|A [[Jakaltek people|Jakaltek]] Maya holds a clay pellet between his lips as he prepares to insert it into his blowgun in [[Guatemala]]. File:BlowgunJacaltekMaya.jpg|A Jakaltek [[Maya peoples|Maya]] hunter aims at the eye of his target and then blows a clay pellet towards it. File:Proffits champetres 9.jpg|Illustration c. 1480 of Medieval Europeans using a blowgun to hunt birds. </gallery>
==Materials==
Darts are typically made of hardwoods to prevent cracking, although bamboo skewers can be used informally. The dart's [[fletching|fletch]] can be made of many materials, such as down, feather tips, and animal fur. Modern materials, such as [[aluminium]] or [[Carbon fiber-reinforced polymer|carbon-reinforced plastic]], are also used.
In Japan, the competition darts are made of cone shaped cellophane plastic rolled into a cone (Fukiya), topped with a non-pointed brass brad. The Japan Sports Fukiya Association JSFA has privatized the sport, and all materials must be purchased from them. International Fukiya Association IFA chairman H.Higuchi promotes worldwise blowgun rule cooperating with other countries.
In other nations, the use of modified piano wire is used to make the {{cvt|0.40|in|mm|0}} cal and {{cvt|0.50|in|mm|0}} cal darts, with certain manufacturers making specialty darts for odd sized or larger caliber barrels ({{cvt|0.35|in|mm|0|disp=sqbr}} cal, {{cvt|0.625|in|mm|0|disp=sqbr}} cal, {{cvt|0.68|in|mm|0|disp=sqbr}} cal, and {{cvt|0.75|in|mm|0|disp=sqbr}} cal).
Use of home-made darts in the larger sizes, or for hunting is common, utilizing bamboo skewers ({{cvt|1/8|and|1/4|in|mm|0|order=flip|disp=or}} diameter), wire coat hangers, and even nails, or knitting needles.
== Specifications == As a primitive weapon, there are no set dimension for a blowgun's length and diameter. However, generally there are several sizes: # '''Fukidake''' — diameter is {{cvt|0.51|in|mm|0|order=flip}} cal in Japan. Tournament length is {{cvt|120|cm|in|0}}, but for practice one can use a {{cvt|50|cm|in|0}} tube. No mouthpiece is used; users wrap their lips around the tube. International versions can be slightly more flexible, allowing a tube of {{cvt|4|ft|cm|0|order=flip}} and {{cvt|0.50|in|mm|order=flip}} cal under IFA rules. Darts consist of a paper cone {{cvt|20|cm|in|0}} long, weighing {{cvt|0.8|g|oz|frac=100}}. # '''Cherokee''' – made of [[Arundinaria|river cane]]<ref>Oosahwee-Voss, Eric. [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/861751870 River Cane: Its Ecological and Cultural Perspectives in Oklahoma Cherokee Culture]. 2012.</ref>, {{cvt|6|to|9|ft|m|0|order=flip}}. Dart is {{cvt|6|to|22|in|cm|0|order=flip}} long and made of [[locustwood]] or other available hardwoods such as oak, ash, maple, walnut, etc., fletched with [[bull thistle]] down or rabbit fur, that provides an air seal.<ref>[http://www.cherokeeheritage.org/cherokeeheritage/cherokee_games.html "Cherokee Games."] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115031310/http://www.cherokeeheritage.org/cherokeeheritage/cherokee_games.html |date=January 15, 2010 }} ''Cherokee Heritage Center.'' (retrieved 19 Dec 2009)</ref> # '''Jakaltek''' wooden blowgun averages {{cvt|3|ft|m|0|order=flip}} long with a sight placed {{cvt|30|cm|in}} from the end. Clay pellets are the most common type of ammunition and clay is sometimes added under the sight when the diameter of the blowgun is too thin for more stability and a better aim. # '''Modern''' (US/EU) — typically has a diameter of {{cvt|0.40|in|mm|0}} cal, however, both the {{cvt|0.50|in|mm|0}} cal and {{cvt|0.625|in|mm|0}} cal are admitted for competitive shooting, with restrictions on barrel length and darts dimensions/weight; with varying lengths having distance restrictions imposed. Bell-shaped mouthpiece. Standard length limited to {{cvt|121|cm|in}} in IFA sanctioned competition. # '''Paintball marker''' — made to be identical to the size of a {{cvt|0.68|in|mm|0}} cal paintball.
==Legality== A law was passed in [[Guatemala]] in the 1930s outlawing the use of the blowgun in an effort to protect small game. It was difficult to enforce in rural areas, but was one of the reasons for the decline of blowgun use in Guatemala.<ref>Edwin Shook. Blowguns in Guatemala. In Notes of Middle American Archaeology and Ethnology, III, no. 67, pp. 37-43. AMS Press, New York, 1946.</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom]] under the [[Criminal Justice Act 1988]], and in [[Australia]], the blowgun is categorized as an offensive weapon, and as such it is illegal to manufacture, sell or hire or offer for sale or hire, expose or have in one's possession for the purpose of sale or hire, or lend or give to any other person. [[Antique]] blowguns are, however, exempt.<ref>{{UK SI | year = 1988 | number = 2019 | url = http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/1988/2019/made | title = The Criminal Justice Act 1988 (Offensive Weapons) Order 1988 | made = 17 November 1988 | force = 18 January 1989 }}</ref>
In [[Canada]], the blowgun is classified as a prohibited weapon and is defined as any device that "being a tube or pipe designed for the purpose of shooting arrows or darts by the breath".<ref>{{cite book |last = Department of Justice Canada |authorlink = Department of Justice Canada |title = Regulations Prescribing Certain Firearms and other Weapons, Components and Parts of Weapons, Accessories, Cartridge Magazines, Ammunition and Projectiles as Prohibited or Restricted (SOR/98-462) |date = 1998-12-01 |chapter = Part 3. Section 12. |chapterurl = http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/ShowDoc/cr/SOR-98-462/bo-ga:s_7::sc:1/20070529/en?page=2&isPrinting=false#codesc:1-bo-ga:l_3-gb:s_12-se:12 |accessdate=2007-05-29}}</ref> Any imported blowgun must be deactivated by either drilling a hole or by blocking it.
In the [[Republic of Ireland]], blowpipes (blow guns) are classified as illegal offensive weapons.<ref>http://www.justice.ie/en/JELR/Pages/FAQ</ref><ref>http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1991/si/66/made/en/print</ref>
In the [[US State]] of [[California]], blowguns are illegal.<ref>[http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/displaycode?section=pen&group=20001-21000&file=20010-20015 CA Penal Code §20010] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307004547/http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/cgi-bin/displaycode?section=pen&group=20001-21000&file=20010-20015# |date=2016-03-07 }} ''California Legislative Information'' (retrieved 01 Feb 2016)</ref> They are also illegal in [[Massachusetts]] and the [[District of Columbia]], but are legal elsewhere. There is currently no age requirement for using a blowgun.<ref>[http://usblowgun.com/legal.html "Legal and Safety Notices." ''United States Blowgun Association.'' (retrieved 19 Dec 2009)]</ref>

{{infobox country at games | NPC = BOT | NPCname = Paralympic Association of Botswana | games = Paralympics | year = | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 1 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = {{Team appearances list|team=Botswana|competition=Summer Paralympics|begin_year=|end_year= }} | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Botswana]]''' made its [[Paralympic Games]] début at the [[2004 Summer Paralympics]] in [[Athens]], sending a single representative ([[Tshotlego Morama]]) to compete in athletics. Morama entered only the women's 400m T46 sprint, and won gold, setting a world record time of 55.99. No further athletes from Botswana have competed at the Summer Games, and Botswana has never taken part in the [[Winter Paralympics]] - leaving the country with a 100% gold medal success rate so far.[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=BOT&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Botswana at the Paralympics], [[International Paralympic Committee]] After her gold medal in Athens, Morama was due to [[Botswana at the 2008 Summer Paralympics|represent Botswana]] again at the [[2008 Summer Paralympics]] in [[Beijing]], in the hopes of defending her title. She would have been the country's only representative.[http://chinaolympicsblog.com/2008/07/14/tshotlego-for-paralympics-dailynews/ "Tshotlego for Paralympics"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813132249/http://chinaolympicsblog.com/2008/07/14/tshotlego-for-paralympics-dailynews/ |date=2011-08-13 }}, Dailynews, Botswana government website, July 14, 2008 However, she withdrew prior to the Games due to injury and, shortly before the Games began, it was announced the country's (unspecified) other athletes, who might have replaced her, had been "rejected by organisers because they do not meet the qualifying criteria", namely having participated in international events.[https://archive.is/20121130125415/http://72.167.255.126/index.php?sid=8&aid=33&dir=2008/September/Friday5 "Botswna locked out of Paralympics"], ''Mmegi'', 5 September 2008 For the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] in [[London]], the country [[Botswana at the 2012 Summer Paralympics|selected]] a single athlete, visually impaired runner Tshotlego Golden, who would take part in the men's 200m sprint (T13). Again, however, Botswana was forced to withdraw at the last moment, mere hours before the opening ceremony. This time the country's withdrawal was due to the Botswana National Olympic Committee cancelling its financial support, citing "financial irregularities" in the national Paralympics body.[https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2012/aug/30/paralympics-malawi-botswana-withdraw-teams?newsfeed=true "Paralympics 2012: Malawi and Botswana withdraw teams"], ''The Guardian'', 30 August 2012[http://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?sid=8&aid=907&dir=2012/August/Friday31 "Paralympic athlete's participation botched"], ''Mmegi'', 31 August 2012 ==Full results for Botswana at the Paralympics== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Name !Games !Sport !Event !Score !Rank |- | [[Tshotlego Morama]] || [[2004 Summer Paralympics|2004 Athens]] || [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Women's 400 m T46 || heats: 57.09 (1st)
final: 55.99 || {{gold medal}} (WR) |} ==See also== * [[Botswana at the Olympics]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Nations at the Paralympics}} [[Category:Botswana at the Paralympics| ]] {{Botswana-sport-stub}} {{Paralympics-stub}}

Primeiro de Agosto sections}} '''[[Clube Desportivo Primeiro de Agosto]]''' is an [[Angola]]n multisports club based in [[Luanda]]. The club is attached to the Angolan Armed Forces which is its main sponsor. The club's men's and women's [[team handball|handball]] teams compete at the local level, at the Luanda Provincial Handball Championship and at the Angolan [[Angola Men's Handball League|Men's]] and [[Angola Women's Handball League|Women's]] leagues as well as at continental level, at the annual [[African Handball Champions League]] competitions. ==Primeiro de Agosto Men's Handball== ===Honours: {{distinguish|text = [[Millennium Stadium]], Cardiff}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Cardiff City Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = [[File:Cardiff City Stadium logo.jpg|247px]] | image = [[File:Cardiff City Stadium Pitch.jpg|300px]] | location = [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]] | coordinates = {{coord|51|28|22|N|3|12|11|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = September 2007 | opened = 22 July 2009 | demolished = | owner = [[Cardiff City F.C.]] | operator = Cardiff City Stadium Ltd | surface = [[Desso GrassMaster]] | construction_cost = [[Pound sterling|£]]48 million | architect = [[Arup Group Limited|Arup Associates]] | former_names = | publictransit = {{rail-interchange|gb|Rail}} {{rws|Ninian Park}}
{{rail-interchange|gb|Rail}} {{rws|Grangetown}} | tenants = [[Cardiff Blues]] (2009–2012)
[[Cardiff City F.C.]] (2009–present)
[[Wales national football team]] (2009-present) | seating_capacity = 33,280{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/tickets/stadium_visitors/ |title=Stadium Visitors |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |accessdate=13 May 2015}}{{not in source|date=May 2018}} }} The '''Cardiff City Stadium''' ({{lang-cy|Stadiwm Dinas Caerdydd}}) is a stadium in the [[Leckwith, Cardiff|Leckwith]] area of [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]]. It is the home of [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City Football Club]] and the [[Wales national football team]]. Following expansion of the Ninian Stand in July 2014, the stadium officially holds 33,280 supporters. The stadium replaced [[Ninian Park]] as Cardiff City's home ground in 2009, and is managed by Cardiff City Stadium Ltd., which is owned by Cardiff City Football Club Holdings Ltd. It also hosted the home matches of the [[Cardiff Blues]] rugby union team until the 2011–12 season, although originally the Blues had a lease until 2029.{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~1318602,00.html |title=CITY AND BLUES SIGN STADIUM CONTRACT |publisher=Cardiff City |accessdate=6 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081105102633/http://www.cardiffcityfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~1318602%2C00.html |archivedate=5 November 2008 |df=dmy-all }}[http://www.cardiffblues.com/news/5207.php Cardiff Blues: New Landmark at Cardiff City Stadium][https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20100120214219/http://wales.gov.uk/location/south_east_wales/latestnews/090406stadium/?lang=en WAG: First Minister visits new Cardiff dual code stadium][http://www.cardiffblues.com/33_4360.php Cardiff Blues Fans Urged to Walk the Blue Mile] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715174339/http://www.cardiffblues.com/33_4360.php |date=15 July 2009 }}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/wales/7002590.stm |work=BBC News |title=Cardiff teams agree ground share |date=19 September 2007 |accessdate=28 April 2010 }} After the [[Millennium Stadium]], it is the second largest stadium in Cardiff and in Wales. The stadium is part of the [[Leckwith development]], which also includes the [[Cardiff International Sports Stadium]]. A branded sponsor name will be assigned as and when the naming rights are sold. The stadium was officially opened on 22 July 2009, with Cardiff City playing a [[friendly match]] against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8012041.stm BBC News Celtic to open new Cardiff ground][http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8164021.stm Cardiff City 0–0 Celtic] ==Overview== The stadium was built on the site of the former [[Cardiff Athletics Stadium]] and forms part of the larger [[Leckwith development]]. The {{convert|60|acre|m2|adj=on}} development was estimated to cost £100m and include construction of the following: *A 28,018[https://web.archive.org/web/20090531153033/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~1675152%2C00.html STADIUM NEWS – Official Cardiff City F.C. Website ] seater stadium *A new athletics stadium ([[Cardiff International Sports Stadium]]) *{{convert|470000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} retail development between 13 major retailers (Capital Retail Park) *A housing development on the site of [[Ninian Park]] *Brand new 70 room hotel with bar & restaurant *A new road system {{wide image|Cardiff City Stadium - panoramic.jpg|1000px|align-cap=center|Inside Cardiff City Stadium}} ==History== ===Background to construction === First mooted as a long term target by former owner [[Sam Hammam]], the new stadium first gained public approval after a meeting between Hammam and then [[Cardiff]] [[Lord Mayor]] [[Russell Goodway]] in January 2002, giving the club 12 months to agree a planning and business plan.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/1763900.stm |work=BBC News |title=Hammam's stadium plan challenge |date=16 January 2002 |accessdate=28 April 2010 }} In November 2002 the club and [[Cardiff Council]] signed an outline agreement for the development, subject to later agreement for outline planning permission.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/2465285.stm |work=BBC News |title=Hammam scores stadium plan win |date=13 November 2002 |accessdate=28 April 2010 }} In March 2003, stories began to emerge that the Chief Executive of the [[Millennium Stadium]] wanted Cardiff City to use their stadium instead, and saw no viable plan for two 50,000+ seat capacity stadia in the Welsh capital.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/2943982.stm |work=BBC News |title=Tug-of-war over Cardiff stadia |date=28 May 2003 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} This was increased in light of Cardiff City's promotion to the Championship in May 2003 with local fears over traffic and access problems.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/3146571.stm |work=BBC News |title=Traffic worries over stadium plan |date=13 August 2003 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} However, on 20 August 2003 Cardiff councillors gave unanimous approval to the stadium plans, although expressed concerns over the need and scale of the retail development but understood its need to fund the stadium.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/3167045.stm |work=BBC News |title=Cardiff stadium gets green light |date=20 August 2003 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} On 9 September 2003 the [[Welsh Assembly]] gave approval to the plan.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/3093064.stm |work=BBC News |title=Road clear for Bluebirds' stadium |date=9 September 2003 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} In April 2004, Cardiff Council gave the first phase covering the stadium with a capacity of 30,000 seats and new athletics track approval.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/3649535.stm |work=BBC News |title=Cardiff's stadium takes next step |date=22 April 2004 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} The next phase was held up by various legal and technical delays from November 2004{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/4096447.stm |work=BBC News |title=Stadium retail plans held up |date=15 December 2004 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} to January 2005, when the council gave approval to three detailed plans for the retail development, subject to agreement of suitable underlying business plans.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/4189805.stm |work=BBC News |title=Work on stadium 'to start in May' |date=20 January 2005 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} Although development could have then started in May 2005, the underlying need for seed financing revealed the financial status of Cardiff City football club as poor, with over £30 million of debt and the need to sell star player and club captain [[Graham Kavanagh]] to [[Wigan Athletic F.C.]] in March 2005. It was also revealed that players and staff had not been paid for a month as the club struggled to honour a wage bill believed to be £750,000 a month, while auditors were looking at possible cutbacks.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/4317345.stm |work=BBC News |title=Wigan complete Kavanagh signing |date=4 March 2005 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} On 1 March 2005 the club delayed the development until at least July 2005.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/4309303.stm |work=BBC News |title=Cardiff stadium work put on hold |date=1 March 2005 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} After a 1–0 home loss to [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] and a mobbing by fans, on 6 March 2005 Hammam apologised to fans, and released club accounts which showed club debt at March 2004 at £29.6 million. After a summer sale of players, the entry of former [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] chairman [[Peter Ridsdale]] and numerous rumours, the development was given a period of 90 days from 31 December 2005 by Cardiff Council to finalise the underlying business plan.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/4487598.stm |work=BBC News |title=Club's deadline over new stadium |date=1 December 2005 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} On 31 January 2006 the developers secured [[Asda]] as the lead retailer of the new development, which enabled the final funding of the stadium to start.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/4664942.stm |work=BBC News |title='Watershed' for city stadium deal |date=31 January 2006 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} This allowed the council timetable to extend by four months to September 2006.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/4998356.stm |work=BBC News |title=Extra time for football stadium |date=20 May 2006 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} On 24 October 2006 Laing O'Rouke won the contract to develop the 30,000 seat stadium, which Ridsdale stated would be ready for December 2008.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/6080058.stm |work=BBC News |title=Cardiff set out new stadium plans |date=24 October 2006 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} On 27 November 2006 Cardiff Council approved the business plan for the stadium, and granted a 125-year lease for the land on which the stadium was to sit upon, allowing the final planning approval to be gained from the council authority and the office of the [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/6187810.stm |work=BBC News |title=New boost for Bluebirds' stadium |date=27 November 2006 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} In March 2007, the stadium plans were altered to allow construction to begin as soon as possible. To minimise construction costs, the 30,000 capacity was reduced to 25,000 by removing three-quarters of the second tier of seating, however the plans allow the option of completing the second tier to reach the 30,000 capacity if required.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/6451593.stm |work=BBC News |title=Cardiff reduce stadium capacity |date=15 March 2007 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} The former chairman of Cardiff City, Steve Borley, said in March 2008 that "We are working to raise the capacity and right now it stands at 26,830. The task is to raise that even further, and we believe it could be almost 28,000 when the stadium opens."[http://icwales.icnetwork.co.uk/footballnation/cardiff-city-fc/2008/03/07/cardiff-director-borley-put-a-figure-on-new-stadium-91466-20573902/ Cardiff director Borley put a figure on new stadium] When work finally commenced Peter Ridsdale stated that he expected the stadium to be ready by Christmas 2008 but it was finally completed in May 2009. Although some believe this slight delay was caused by Cardiff City's ongoing legal action with Langston, it was actually caused by unexpectedly poor weather during the summer of 2007.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/6983963.stm |work=BBC News |title=City ground 'delayed to May 2009' |date=7 September 2007 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} ===Stadium construction === {{multiple image | header = Construction of the Cardiff City Stadium | width = 250 | direction = vertical | image1 = Demolish of the "Old" Leckwith Stadium Cardiff.jpg | caption1 = Demolition of the [[Cardiff Athletics Stadium]] in November 2007 | image2 = Cardiff City Stadium during construction.jpg | caption2 = The Canton Stand ''(left)'' and Ninian Stand ''(right)'' during construction, July 2008 | image3 = Cardiff City Stadium - outside.jpg | caption3 = Completion of the Canton Stand ''(left)'' and the Grandstand ''(right)'' }} Land clearance started on 21 February 2007,{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/6382017.stm |work=BBC News |title=Work starts on Bluebirds stadium |date=21 February 2007 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} while on 9 May, final finances were put in place for Laing O'Rourke to bring equipment on site and start construction.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/6642615.stm |work=BBC News |title=Final go-ahead for city stadium |date=10 May 2007 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} '''Developers and contractors''' The lead developer was PMG Developments, a Cardiff-based property developer led by Cardiff City director Paul Guy and former Wales [[Rugby Union|rugby]] captain [[Mike Hall (rugby union)|Mike Hall]]. Laing O'Rourke were contracted to build all the highway improvements necessary to cope with the increased capacity, as well as the demolition of the Cardiff Athletics Stadium and the construction of the retail park. Cowlin was picked as the preferred contractor for the new athletic stadium. Required analysis of soil and water for the site was performed by TES Bretby, part of the Environmental Services Group Ltd. {{citation needed|date=August 2015}} '''Schedule''' Leckwith Road was widened to a dual carriageway over 18 months, with the scheme allowing for an extra access lane to become available on matchdays. {{citation needed|date=August 2015}} The plan required the demolition of the previous Cardiff Athletics Stadium, of which the council insisted the replacement is built before the start of construction on the new football stadium. This was to avoid the city being without a major athletics facility for any length of time. {{citation needed|date=August 2015}} Work was scheduled to begin on the new athletics stadium in January 2007 with the track and throwing areas expected to be open for use by the end of July 2007. The new athletics stadium was expected to be completed by October 2007 and it was hoped that Cardiff City F.C.'s stadium would be able to open in December 2008, however the stadium finally completed in May 2009. '''Detailed timetable''' *27 November 2006: Stadium business plan approved by Cardiff Council *November 2006: Three-month period began for possible legal challenge to deal. The council also had to receive approval from the National Assembly for disposal of the Leckwith land at less than market value *Early 2007: Work started *Early Spring 2007: Building of the retail park begin along with the major highways works around Leckwith Road *Summer 2007: New athletics track finished around the middle of the summer *October 2007: Commence main contract works *Christmas 2007: Complete demolition works *January 2007: Commence piling *March 2007: Commence steelwork *Summer 2008: Commence cladding *Autumn 2008: Complete structure *October 2008: West stand weathertight *Christmas 2008: Fit-out access *January 2009: Power on *May 2009: Stadium completed[http://www.cardiffcitystadium.co.uk/index.php?view=article&catid=8%3Anews&id=35%3Astadium-trivia&option=com_content&Itemid=48 Stadium Trivia | Official Stadium Website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807192245/http://www.cardiffcitystadium.co.uk/index.php?view=article&catid=8%3Anews&id=35%3Astadium-trivia&option=com_content&Itemid=48 |date=7 August 2011 }} In August 2007, chairman [[Peter Ridsdale]] revealed that the club had reduced a £24 million debt to Swiss-based financiers Langston agreed under the chairmanship of [[Sam Hammam]] to £15 million, by agreeing to sell the stadium's naming rights to Langston for £9 million.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/6948498.stm |work=BBC News |title=Cardiff chief rejects debt claim |date=15 August 2007 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} The stadium name was unveiled in March 2009 as Cardiff City Stadium and on 1 May, the official logo of the Cardiff City Stadium and the management company Cardiff City Stadium Ltd was unveiled.{{cite web |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~1645239,00.html |title=CARDIFF CITY STADIUM: LOGO LAUNCH |publisher=Cardiff City FC |accessdate=6 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120809120232/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~1645239%2C00.html |archivedate=9 August 2012 |df=dmy-all }}[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/bluebirds-ground-named-the-cardiff-2119345 WalesOnline – FootballNation – Football News – Bluebirds ground named ‘The Cardiff City Stadium’] [[File:Cardiff City Stadium - Cardiff City Vs Celtic.jpg|thumb|The official opening match between Cardiff City and [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] on 22 July 2009]] The stadium was completed several weeks ahead of schedule and was officially opened with a pre-season friendly against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] on 22 July 2009, which ended in a 0–0 draw.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8012041.stm Celtic to open new Cardiff ground], [[BBC Sport]].[http://www.thecelticwiki.com/page/2009-07-22%3A+Cardiff+City+0-0+Celtic,+Friendly.] There were two games played in the stadium prior to this: a Cardiff City Legends game on 4 July, and a friendly against [[Chasetown F.C.|Chasetown]] on 10 July. The first [[The Football League|league]] game was played on 8 August 2009, a 4–0 win for Cardiff against [[Scunthorpe United]]. [[Wales national football team|Wales]] played at the Cardiff City Stadium for the first time on 14 November 2009 against [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]], which they won 3–0. On 10 August 2010, the [[Football Association of Wales]] announced that it would also play at the Stadium in Wales' opening game of the [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying|UEFA Euro 2012 qualifiers]] against [[Bulgaria national football team|Bulgaria]] on 8 October 2010.{{cite news |title=WALES EURO OPENER @ CCS |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~2117763,00.html |work=cardiffcityfc.co.uk |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |date=10 August 2010 |accessdate=10 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324115654/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~2117763%2C00.html |archivedate=24 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} On 8 May 2012, Cardiff Blues confirmed they would leave the Stadium to return to [[Cardiff Arms Park]] for the 2012–13 season and onwards.{{cite news |title=Cardiff City & Blues Agreement |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~2763805,00.html |publisher=Cardiff City Football Club Official Site |date=8 May 2012 |accessdate=8 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529235227/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~2763805%2C00.html |archivedate=29 May 2012 |df=dmy-all }} === Stadium expansion === [[File:Ninian Stand development April 18, 2014.jpeg|thumb|left|The Ninian Stand new development 18 April 2014]] On 14 June 2012 [[Vincent Tan]], Malaysian co-owner of Cardiff City FC, set out plans for an additional £35m investment in the Championship football club. This investment is to pay off debts, upgrade the training facilities to Premier League standards and spend £12m upgrading the stadium's capacity by 8,000 seats from 26,828 to around 35,000. The stadium can also be upgraded again to 60,000 seats but this won't happen unless Cardiff become a big European club. The stand(s) that will be upgraded have not been announced yet but it will likely be the Ninian stand and possibly another, as there are only private boxes available on the grandstand. It is possible more than one stand could be upgraded in order to reduce the impact of one tall stand.{{cite news |title=Cardiff City's Malaysian owners outline £100m investment plan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18445138 |work=BBC Sport |date=14 June 2012 |accessdate=14 June 2012}} On 1 August, [[Peter's Food Services|Peter's Pie]] became the official sponsor of the Family Stand on a two-year deal.{{cite news |title=Peter's Pie score City family deal |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~2867631,00.html |work=Cardiff City F.C. |publisher=Official Site |date=1 August 2012 |accessdate=1 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120904023340/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~2867631%2C00.html |archivedate=4 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }} In April 2013 it was announced by a Cardiff City director that the capacity at the stadium could be expanded to 35,000 before the beginning of the 2014/15 season.{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/cardiff-city-could-see-stadium-2998180 |work=[[Wales Online]]|title=Cardiff City could see stadium expanded to 35,000 seats by 2014/5 season|date=24 April 2013|accessdate=23 June 2013}} Extra seats were added around the stadium during the first few months of the 2013–14 season, increasing the capacity to around 28,000. {{citation needed|date=August 2015}} In August 2013 the club announced it had submitted a planning application to the local authority for the first phase of a stadium expansion.{{cite web|title=Stadium Phase One Development|url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/stadium-phase-one-development-994444.aspx|publisher=Cardiff City Football Club|accessdate=6 September 2013}} Phase 1 will entail adding a second tier to the Ninian Stand increasing the capacity to approximately 33,280. 5,150 extra seats are to be provided, including extra commercial and hospitality facilities catering for around 1500. {{citation needed|date=August 2015}} On 9 October 2013 the local authority granted planning permission for this first phase.{{cite news|title=Cardiff City Stadium expansion given green light|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-stadium-expansion-given-6164476|accessdate=13 October 2013|newspaper=Wales Online|date=9 October 2013}} The stadium expansion was completed at the beginning of August, a few weeks before the stadium was due to host the [[UEFA Super Cup]]. At a later stage, phases 2 and 3 of the development will see up to 3,000 seats added to both the Canton and Grange ends of the ground, bringing the overall capacity up to around 38,000. {{citation needed|date=August 2015}} However, in March 2015, it was announced that the Ninian Stand extension was to be shut for the [[2015–16 Cardiff City F.C. season|2015–16]] season due to poor ticket sales, dropping the capacity to 27,978.{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-citys-new-12m-ninian-8956913 |title=Cardiff City's new £12m Ninian Stand to be mothballed less than a year after opening |work=Wales Online |date=31 March 2015 |accessdate=7 May 2015}} ==Sport venue== [[File:Cardiff City Stadium-front.jpg|thumb|Image taken in April 2011 when the stadium was shared between Cardiff City F.C. and Cardiff Blues]] On 19 September 2007, it was announced that Cardiff City F.C. and Cardiff Blues had signed a Heads of Terms agreement for Cardiff Blues to become tenants of Cardiff City. On 24 May 2008, the two clubs signed a contract officially finalising the deal. The licence agreement was set at 20 years, meaning Cardiff Blues would leave [[Cardiff Arms Park]] and play their home games at the stadium until 2029. ===Football=== As well as being the new home for Cardiff City, the stadium has since become the home of the [[Wales national football team]] except for the international friendly against [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]] which was at [[Parc y Scarlets]] in [[Llanelli]], two [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying Group G]] home matches with the first against [[England national football team|England]] which was at the [[Millennium Stadium]] in [[Cardiff]] and the second against [[Switzerland national football team|Switzerland]] which was at the [[Liberty Stadium]] in [[Swansea]], an international friendly against [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] which was at Parc y Scarlets in Llanelli, another international friendly, which was against [[Austria national football team|Austria]] and a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group A]] match against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]], both of which were at the Liberty Stadium in Swansea. On 12 August 2014 the stadium hosted the [[2014 UEFA Super Cup]] between the [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League]] winners [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and the [[2013–14 UEFA Europa League]] winners [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]]. Real Madrid won 2–0.{{cite news |title=Cardiff City Stadium will play host to UEFA Super Cup in 2014 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2166891/Cardiff-City-Stadium-play-host-UEFA-Super-Cup-2014.html |work=Daily Mail |date=30 June 2012 |accessdate=30 June 2012}} On 1 June 2017 it hosted the [[2017 UEFA Women's Champions League Final|final]] of the [[2016–17 UEFA Women's Champions League]]. ===Rugby=== Between the 2009–10 season and the 2011–12 season, it was the home of the [[Cardiff Blues]]. The Blues left after the 2011–12 season, after a mutual agreement to return to the [[Arms Park]] was agreed.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}The Cardiff City stadium also hosted the [[2010–11 Amlin Challenge Cup]] final between English club [[Harlequin F.C.|Harlequins]] and French club [[Stade Français]] on 20 May 2011 with Harlequins pipping Stade Français 19–18. ==Concert venue== {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=Stereophonics @ Cardiff City Stadium.jpg|image2=Stereophonics, Summer in the City.jpg|width=250|caption2=Stereophonics during ''Summer in the City''}} [[Stereophonics]] headlined the first gig at the stadium on 5 June 2010, having already played a record-breaking 13 previous sell-out shows at the [[Cardiff International Arena]], as well as at the [[Millennium Stadium]] and [[Cardiff Castle]].[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/cardiff-news/2010/01/20/stereophonics-confirm-gig-at-cardiff-city-stadium-91466-25638200/ WalesOnline – News – Cardiff News – Stereophonics confirm gig at Cardiff City Stadium] The concert, known as ''Summer in the City'', was supported by [[Kids In Glass Houses]] and [[Doves (band)|Doves]]. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center width=60%" |- !style="text-align:center"|Date !style="text-align:center"|Artist !style="text-align:center"|Tour/concert !style="text-align:center"|Support acts |- |align=center|5 June 2010||align=center|[[Stereophonics]]||align=center|Summer in the City||align=center|[[Doves (band)|Doves]]
[[Kids in Glass Houses]] |- |align=center|12 June 2013||align=center|[[Bon Jovi]]||align=center|[[Because We Can: The Tour]]||align=center|[[Kids in Glass Houses]] |- |align=center|4 June 2016||align=center|[[Stereophonics]]||align=center|Keep the Summer Alive||align=center|[[The Vaccines]]
[[Band of Skulls]] |- |align=center|11 June 2016||align=center|[[Rod Stewart]]||align=center|[[Hits 2016 (Rod Stewart tour)|Hits 2016]]||align=center|The Mariarchis
The Sisterhood[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/everything-you-need-know-rod-11438025 WalesOnline – Everything you need to know about Rod Stewart’s gig at Cardiff City Stadium] |} ==Transport== The stadium and surrounding area is served by [[Ninian Park railway station]] (on the [[Cardiff City Line]]) on one side of Sloper Road, by and [[Grangetown railway station]] (on the [[Vale of Glamorgan Line]]) on the other side.http://www.projectmapping.co.uk/Reviews/Resources/Valley%20lines%20(TR%20UK%20508).jpg Trains operate frequently to [[Cardiff Central railway station|Central]] and [[Cardiff Queen Street|Queen Street]] stations in the [[Cardiff city centre|city centre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arrivatrainswales.co.uk/uploadedFiles/Documents/Timetables/Timetable%20expDec09.pdf |accessdate=9 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902050114/http://www.arrivatrainswales.co.uk/uploadedFiles/Documents/Timetables/Timetable%20expDec09.pdf |archivedate=2 September 2009 }} [[Cardiff Bus]] service 95 between Central Station and [[Barry Island]] stops outside the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.cardiffbus.com/pdfs/r95.pdf |accessdate=9 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219070553/http://www.cardiffbus.com/pdfs/r95.pdf |archivedate=19 February 2009 }} The stadium is next to Leckwith Interchange on the [[A4232 road|A4232]] dual carriageway, linking it northbound to the [[A48 road|A48]] and [[M4 motorway|M4 (J33 Cardiff West)]] and southbound to [[Cardiff Bay]] and the city centre. There is limited parking at the stadium itself. Some spaces are available on a first-come, first-served basis, but most are pre-allocated to season ticket holders. ==Statues== [[File:Fred Keenor at Cardiff City Stadium, Cardiff.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Fred Keenor]] statue outside the Stadium.]] On 17 December 2009, Cardiff City confirmed a statue of 1927 [[FA Cup]]-winning captain [[Fred Keenor]] would be built.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/8418174.stm |work=BBC News |title=Fans pick cup hero statue design |date=17 December 2009 |accessdate=28 April 2010}} In May 2012, the £85,000 needed to build the statue was raised by the Cardiff City Supporters Trust and was revealed on 10 November 2012.{{cite news |title=Cardiff City fans get first glimpse of 9ft Fred Keenor statue |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/footballnation/cardiff-city/cardiff-city-fc/2012/05/16/cardiff-city-fans-get-first-glimpse-of-9ft-fred-keenor-statue-91466-30975588/? |work=South Wales Echo |date=16 May 2012 |accessdate=16 May 2012}}{{cite news |title=A tribute to Cardiff City legend Fred Keenor |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/cardiffonline/cardiff-football/2012/11/10/a-tribute-to-cardiff-city-legend-fred-keenor-91466-32202950/ |work=South Wales Echo |date=10 November 2012 |accessdate=9 November 2012}} ==Statistics== *Capacity: 33,280 (approx) *Record attendance: 33,280 ([[Wales national football team|Wales]] vs [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]]), 12 June 2015 *Record attendance for a [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] match: 32,478 v Reading FC 6 May 2018 {{cite web |url=http://www.insidewalessport.co.uk/cardiff-city-reading-report/ |title=Cardiff City 0–0 The '''Chess'n Math Association''' (or '''Chess and Math Association''') is a non-profit organization dedicated to bringing chess into Canadian schools. Founded in 1985 by [[Larry Bevand]], who still serves as its Executive Director, it bills itself as "[[Canada]]'s National Scholastic Chess Organization", although it is not affiliated with the [[Chess Federation of Canada]], Canada's official [[FIDE]]-recognized chess organization. Chess'n Math runs hundreds of tournaments for kids [[K-12]] across Canada, including an annual Canadian Chess Challenge. These tournaments are rated according to its own rating system. It also offers chess lessons and camps, produces a magazine ''Scholar's Mate'', and runs the ''Strategy'' game stores located in [[Montreal]], [[Ottawa]] and [[Toronto]]. CMA has sponsored several chess futurity events, to provide international title norm opportunities for promising young Canadian players.
==Publications== *Leçons d'échecs du Tournoi International de Montréal 2001 by IM [[Jean Hébert]] *Le Livre du Tournoi International de Montréal 2002 by IM [[Jean Hébert]] *Chess Strategy for Kids by Jeff Coakley *Winning Chess Exercises for Kids by Jeff Coakley *Winning Chess Puzzles for Kids by Jeff Coakley *Nick's Best by IM [[Lawrence Day]] about IM [[Bryon Nickoloff]] * Chess on the Edge by GM [[Yasser Seirawan]] and FM Bruce Harper, the games of GM [[Duncan Suttles]] in three volumes.
==Rating System==
The Chess 'n Math rating system does not differ from that of the FIDE a lot in the way that the formula is derived, but the variables are different. According to their website,<ref>[http://www.chess-math.org/ratings/calculat.htm Calculating<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829164756/http://www.chess-math.org/ratings/calculat.htm |date=August 29, 2008 }}</ref> the formula is as follows, for one tournament or multi-game event:
<math>R_n = R_o + (W-L) \times 16 + D * 0.04\ </math>
: Where W is the number of wins, L is the number of losses, and D is the difference in rating (your opponent's minus yours), with a cutoff value of ±350.
As it appears, the number of "expected wins" for one game is equal to the difference in rating divided by 800, plus 0.5. The cutoff value of ±350 makes the limits of these "We" values, 15/16 and 1/16 respectively. A person can also win bonus points equal to:
<math>Bonus = (R_n - R_o - (18 + 2 \times G));\ \ \ min(Bonus)=0</math>
: for doing extremely well in a series of games. (G stands for number of games played).
As of September 1, 2007, a "bonus" of 2 is added to every game won, up to a maximum of 50 games.

{{Other uses|Chin Music (disambiguation){{!}}Chin Music}} '''''Chin music''''' is a slang term with several different meanings.
==American street slang== In American [[slang]], ''chin music'' is a term for idle talk. It dates back at least a century: "There's too much chin music an' too little fightin' in this war, anyhow" is a quote from Stephen Crane's 1895 novel ''[[The Red Badge of Courage]]''. It can alternatively be used as a euphemism for punching someone in the jaw.
==Baseball==
In [[baseball]] slang, it means a pitch that is thrown near the batter's face. The [[pitcher]]'s intent may be to cause the batter to move "back" such that it is more difficult to hit a future outside pitch, to frighten the [[Baseball#Batting|batter]] into a poorer batting approach, to intimidate opposing batters, or to actually hit the batter with the pitch. If the [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] suspects the pitcher of either of the latter two intentions, he may eject the pitcher immediately or warn both teams that any similar pitch will result in automatic ejection. The pitcher's manager may also be ejected or warned if the umpire believes the manager ordered the [[beanball]].
In the late 1800s, at baseball's inception, the phrase "chin music" was used to describe razzing or heckling from the fans. It began being used as a synonym for a [[brushback pitch]] around [[World War II]].
==Cricket==
In [[cricket]], chin music is a term for a [[bowling (cricket)|bowling]] strategy where [[bouncer (cricket)|bouncers]] are aimed at the batsman's throat or chin.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cricket/vaughan-is-ready-to-face-west-indies-chin-music-578529.html Vaughan is ready to face West Indies' 'chin music'], Independent, Retrieved on 14 June 2009</ref> Rising rapidly off the pitch, the ball is difficult to play unless the batsman has quick footwork. If fended rather than avoided, it may yield a ballooned return catch to the bowler or to close-in fielders. This is a difficult ball to bowl, since a few inches on either side would present the batsman with a short ball that can be easily put away on either side of the [[cricket pitch|pitch]]. It is not illegal in cricket, but the number of short deliveries allowed in an over is usually restricted, and bowlers who exceed this may get a warning from the [[Umpire (cricket)|umpire]]. This tactic was made famous by the [[England cricket team|England team]] in the controversial '[[Bodyline]]' [[The Ashes|Ashes]] series in 1932.

([[Castellón de la Plana|Castellón]], Spain; 11 June 2009) | pattern_la1=_Estonia | pattern_b1=_neck_stripe_white | pattern_ra1=_Estonia | pattern_sh1=_manutd1011a | pattern_so1=_Est_long | leftarm1=0247FE | body1=0247FE | rightarm1=0247FE | shorts1=000000 | socks1=none | pattern_la2=_Estonia2 | pattern_b2=_Est3 | pattern_ra2=_Estonia2 | pattern_sh2=_manutd1011a | pattern_so2=_Est_long2 |leftarm2=0247FE | body2=0247FE | rightarm2=0247FE | shorts2=000000 | socks2=none }} The '''Estonia national beach soccer team''' represents [[Estonia]] in international [[beach soccer]] competitions and is controlled by the [[Estonian FA]], the governing body for football in [[Estonia]]. The Estonia national football team played their first [[FIFA Beach Soccer World Cup]] qualifier in August 2007, losing 1–3 to [[Ukraine national beach soccer team|Ukraine]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rannajalgpall.ee/index.php/et/koondis |title=Koondis |publisher=Rannajalgpall.ee |date=}} ==Current squad== {{updated|28 August 2016}} {{cite
